questions.content: A body falling freely from a given height H hits an inclined plane in its path at a height h. As a result of this impact, the direction of the velocity of the body becomes horizontal. For what value of hH the body will take maximum time to reach the ground?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
For A to B
u=0
s=-(H-h)
a=-g
using, s=ut+12at2 we get -(H-h)=12(-g)t2
⇒t=2(H-h)g12
For B to C Vertical Motion
uy=0
sy=-h
ay=-g
t=t'
using, s=ut+12at2

-h=-12gt'2  ⇒ t'=2hg

∴ Total time of fall T=t+t'
or T=2(H-h)g12+2hg12
For finding the maximum time using the concept of differentiation
dTdh=0

⇒ddt2(H-h)g1/2+ddt2hg1/2=0
⇒122(H-h)g-1/2×-2g+122hg-1/22g=0
⇒2(H-h)g-1/2=2hg-1/2
⇒2(H-h)g=2hg
⇒H-h=h
⇒hH=12

questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
F.B.D. of man and plank are



For plank to be at rest, applying Newton's second law to plank along the incline

Mgsinα=f                   ...(1)

and applying Newton's second law to man along the incline.

mgsinα+f=ma           ...(2)

a=gsinα1+Mm down the incline

questions.content: A particle is projected vertically upwards with a speed of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>16</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>, after some time, when it again passes through the point of projection, its speed is found to be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. It is found that the work done by air resistance is the same during upward and downward motion. Then the maximum height attained by the particle is –
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
From work energy theorem

for upward motion,

12m 162=mgh+W

for downward motion

12m 82=mgh – W

h=8 m

questions.content: A force <math><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">α</mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover></math> is acting at a point <math><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi></mrow><mo>^</mo></mover></math> . questions.content: A network of four capacitors of capacity equal to C1=C, C2=2C, C3=3C and C4=4C, are connected to a battery as shown in the figure. The ratio of the charges on C2 and C4 is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
C1, C2 and C3 are in series

      1 C ′ = 1 C + 1 2 C + 1 3 C

or,  1 C ′ = 6 + 3 + 2 6 C = 1 1 6 C

or,  C ′ = 6 C 1 1

      
All the capacitors in upper branch are in series so the charge on each capacitor is Q ′ = 6 1 1 CV

Also charge on capacitor C4 is Q = 4CV

∴     Ratio = Q ′ Q = 6 CV 1 1 × 4 CV = 3 2 2

questions.content: A simple pendulum of length <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>l</mi></math> is suspended from the ceiling of a cart which is sliding without friction on an inclined plane of inclination <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>θ</mi></math>. questions.explanation:
Here, the point of suspension has an acceleration. a → =gsinθ (down the plane). Further, g→ can be resolved into two components gsinθ (along the plane) and gcosθ (perpendicular to the plane).



g→eff=g→-a→

=gcosθ (perpendicular to plane)
T=2πl|g→eff|

    =2πlgcosθ

Young's modulus, Y=FLAl

or, F=YAlL

or, F∝A or F∝r2 or F∝d2. 

∴ F1F2=d12d22

Given, d1=d,  d2=2d, F1=200 N. 

∴ 200F2=d22d2=14

or, F2=4×200=800 N.

questions.content: The frequency of a sonometer wire is f but when the weights producing tension are completely immersed in water the frequency becomes <math> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </math> and on immersing the weights in certain liquid the frequency becomes <math> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mtext>f</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </math>. The specific gravity of the liquid is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
f ∝ T μ

Let ρ the density of weight.

σ be the density of liquid.

and V be the volume of the weights.

∴   f ∝ V ρ g μ    ...... (1)

∴   f 2 ∝ V ρ - 1 g μ    ...... (2)

∴   f 3 ∝ V ρ - σ g μ    ...... (3)

From (1) and (2)

4 = ρ ρ - 1 ⇒ ρ = 4 3

From (1) and (3)

9 = 4 3 4 3 - σ ⇒ σ = 1.185

questions.content: An electric heater supplies heat to a system at a rate of <math><mn>120</mn><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></math>. If system performs work at a rate of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>80</mn><mi> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>, the rate of increase in internal energy is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
According to first law of thermodynamics,
ΔQ=ΔU+ΔW
where, ∆Q is the heat supplied, ∆U is the change in the internal energy, and ∆W is the work done by the system.
∴ΔQΔt=ΔUΔt+ΔWΔt
Given that, ΔQΔt=120 W
and ΔWΔt=80 J s-1
∴ΔUΔt=120-80=40 J s-1

questions.content: One end of a copper rod of uniform cross-section and of length 1.5 m is kept in contact with ice at 0°C and the other end with water at 100°C. If the whole system is insulated from its surroundings, then at what distance from the end of the rod which is in contact with the steam, the temperature should be maintained at 200°C, so that in steady-state the rate of melting of ice be equal to the rate of production of steam? [Lfusion=80 cal g-1, Lvaporization=540 cal g-1]
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
If the point is at a distance x from water at 100 °C, heat conducted to ice in time t,
Qice=KA200-01.5-x×t

So ice melted by this heat
mice=QiceLF=KA80200-01.5-x×t

Similarly heat conducted by the rod to the water at 100 °C in time t,
Q water = KA 200 - 100 x t
So steam formed by this heat
msteam=QwaterLV=KA200-100540xt
According to the given problem, mice=msteam , i.e.,

200801.5-x=100540xorx=658 m=10.34 cm

i.e., 200 °C temperature must be maintained at a distance 10.34 cm  from water at 100 °C.

questions.content: In Young's double-slit experiment, a mica slab of thickness <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> and refractive index <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>μ</mi></math> is introduced in the ray from one of the slits. By how much distance, fringes pattern will be displaced?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The extra path difference due to the insertion of sheet of refractive index μ and thickness t is,

∆x=(μ-1)t

The shift in interference pattern of Young's double slit experiment  is,
y=Dd∆x⇒y=μ-1tDd

Hence, fringes pattern will be displaced by Ddμ-1t.

questions.content: A ring of mass 4 kg is uniformly charged with a linear charge density λ=4 C m-1 and kept on a rough horizontal surface with a friction coefficient of μ=π4. A time-varying magnetic field B=B0t2 is applied in a circular region of radius a a<r perpendicular to the plane of the ring as shown in the figure. Find out the time (in seconds) when the ring just starts to rotate on the surface. ( Take a=5 cm, g=10 m s-2 and B0=125 T s-2)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Induced electric field,
E(2πr)=dφdt
E=πa22B0t2πr
Torque due to field about centre of ring,
τ1=(qE)r=(λ(2πr))2πa2B0t2πrr
The ring starts rotating when,
τ due to electric field =τ due to friction.
τ1=μmgr
Solving,
t=μmg2πa2B0λ=4 s

questions.content:
A load of 31.4 kg is suspended from a wire of radius 10-3 m and density 9 x 103 kg/m3. The Young's modulus and heat capacity of the material of the wire are 9.8 x 1010 N/m2 and 490 J/kg K respectively. The change in temperature of the wire if 75% of the work done is converted into heat, is 1n K. Then the value of n is:

Take π=3.14
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
As work done in stretching an elastic body per unit volume is given by

              W V = 1 2 stress × strain = 1 2 stress 2 Y      as Y = stress strain      ........ (1)

So         W = 1 2 Mg A 2 V Y            as stress = F A = Mg A

Now according to given problem heat produced H = (75/100)  W = 3 4 .W

              ⇒   ms Δ θ = 3 4 × 1 2 Mg π r 2 2 V Y           as H = ms Δ θ using equation (1)

or          ρ V s Δ θ = 3 4 × 1 2 Mg π r 2 2 V Y         as m = ρ V

∴       Δ θ = 3 8 3 1 . 4 × 9 . 8 π × 1 0 - 6 2 1 9 . 8 × 1 0 1 0 × 1 9 × 1 0 3 × 4 9 0

i.e., Δθ=1120K

questions.content: A tightly wound solenoid of radius ‘a’ and length ‘l’ has n turns per unit length. It carries an electric current i. Magnetic field at a distance l4 from one of the end (inside the solenoid on its axis) is B=μ0ni5+3K for l=4a . Find the value of K.

sinθ1=3a3a2+a2=310

sinθ2=aa2+a2=12


⇒ B=μ0ni212+310
⇒ B=μ0ni5+340
∴ K=40

Let there be no current in ACDBA and there is current i in loop CEFDC
then, applying KVL in Loop CEFDC

⇒+50−iR−20i=0

⇒ i=5020+R  ...1


Now we consider another loop AEFBA for this apply KVL

30-iR-10×0 = 0⇒30 = iR  ...2

(As there is zero current in 10 Ω resistor)

From equation (1) and (2)

5020+RR=30⇒50 R = 600 + 30 R⇒20 R = 600⇒ R = 30 Ω

⇒5x=30 Ω⇒x=6

 2mv'=mv  or v'=v2

questions.content: The electric potential in a region is given as V=–4ar2+3b, where r is distance from the origin, a and b are constants. If the volume charge density in the region is given by ρ=naε0, then what is the value of n?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
V=-4ar2+3b

E=-dV  dr=8ar

The small amount of flux dϕ associated with the closed surface bounded by two spheres of radius r and r+dr is

dϕ=E+dEA+dA-EA

dϕ=EdA+dEA

dE=8adr and dA=8πrdr

Using Gauss's law

ρ×4πr2drε0=8adr×4πr2+8ar×8πrdr

⇒ ρ = 24aε0

n = 24

questions.content: In which one of the following pairs is the radius of the second species greater than that of the first?
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.explanation:
As we move from left to right in a period, the size of the atom decreases. Thus, Mg is smaller than Na.

For isoelectronic species, the size decreases with increase in positive charge. Li+ and Be2+ are isoelectronic. Thus, the size of Be2+ is less than that of Li+.

As we move down the group, the size of the atom increases. Ba and Sr belong to the same group. Ba is below Sr in the group. Thus, the size of Sr2+ is less than that of Ba2+.

For isoelectronic species, the size increases with increase in negative charge. N3- and O2- are isoelectronic.  r N 3 - > r O 2 -  as charge on N3- anion is more.

questions.content: Only two isomeric monochloro derivatives are possible for which of the following?
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Halogenation of alkanes is a free radical substitution reaction.

In 2-methylpropane, two types of hydrogen atoms are present. Total H-atom are 10, out of which nine are 1° H atoms of same type and one H-atom of 3°is present.

Hence, only two substituted products can be formed.

questions.content:
Bond dissociation enthalpy of E—H (E = element) bonds is given below. Which of the compounds will act as strongest reducing agent?
 Compound NH3  PH3 AsH3 SbH3
△diss (E—H)/kJ mol–1 389 322 297 255
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
As the bond dissociation energy decreases reducing nature of the substance increases because the bond can be broken down easily and can donate electron easily and make the other substance to be reduced.

The order of bond dissociation energy of given molecules is NH3​>PH3​>AsH3>SbH3​ due to the increase in the size of the central atom.

So the strongest reducing agent is SbH3​.

questions.content: For the process <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo> </mo><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>bar</mi><mo>, 373</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>⟶</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo> </mo><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>bar</mi><mo>, 373</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>, the correct set of thermodynamic parameters is

For phase change equilibrium, both the phases are in equilibrium.

ΔG=0

Since, the process of conversion of liquid water to gaseous water at 100°C is spontaneous, it will proceed with an increase in entropy.

In other words,

questions.content: A compound <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> gives a positive test of carbonyl group, a negative test with Fehling solution, a positive haloform test and on reduction it gives normal pentane. Identify the compound.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
1) The compound gives a positive test of the carbonyl group, i.e, it is either an aldehyde or a ketone.

2) It gives a negative test with Fehling solution. Hence, it cannot be an aldehyde.

3) A positive iodoform test is given by methyl ketone -COCH3.

4) Also, 2-pentanone on reduction gives pentane.

 Hence, it can be 2-pentanone CH3-CO-CH2-CH2-CH3.

questions.content: How much <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>NaNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> must be weighed out to make <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>50</mn><mo> </mo><mi>ml</mi></math> of an aqueous solution containing <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>70</mn><mo> </mo><mi>mg</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Na</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>mL</mi></math>?
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
As we can see that 1 mL contains 70 mg Na. So, 50 mL contains 50×701000=3.5 g.

Gram atomic mass of sodium = 23 g

No. of moles of sodium =3.523=0.152 

Applying POAC concept, number of moles of Na is equal to the number of moles of NaNO3

Molar mass of NaNO3=85 gmol

So, mass of NaNO3 =0.152×85 =12.92 g

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> bonds are of the same length but shorter than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> bond.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> bonds are of the same length but longer than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> bond.

questions.explanation: Bromine is bulky. So, the NO2 group goes out of the plane. Therefore, C1-N and C3-N bonds are of the same length and longer than the C5-N bond. Bond length is inversely proportional to bond order. Partial double bond character of C5-N bond is comparatively more than that of C1-N and C3-N bonds.

questions.content: How is absolute alcohol prepared?
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation: Absolute alcohol (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mo>%</mo></math> pure ethyl alcohol) is obtained from rectified spirit (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>95</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>87</mn><mo>%</mo></math> ethanol and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>%</mo></math> water) by azeotropic distillation as it is an azeotropic mixture. For this, some benzene is added to rectified spirit. Now, this mixture is distilled when the third fraction (at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>74</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>) contains <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mo>%</mo></math> ethyl alcohol.

questions.content: The order of reactivities of the following alkyl halides for an <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></math> reaction is
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
The nucleophilic substitution reaction like SN2 reactions can be represented as follows

R-X→OH-R-OH+X-

The rate of reaction depends on the ease of leaving group.

The replacement of halide group follows the order I->Br->Cl->F-.
This reactivity order has been explained on the basis of greater bond length (maximum for C-I), which lowers the bond energy and makes the molecule less stable.

Bond energy of C-I<C-Br<C-Cl<C-F.

questions.content: The compound that is both paramagnetic and coloured is
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
K2Cr2O7 contains Cr6+3d0 which is diamagnetic but coloured due to charge transfer spectra. Charge transfer spectra in highly ionic crystals correspond to electron transfer between neighboring atoms. They can be classified as donor or acceptor, depending upon whether the metal atom donates or accepts an electron.

The organge colour of the solution K2Cr2O7 is because an electron from the Oxygen lone pair is transferred to low lying Chromate ion orbital.


NH42TiCl6 contains Ti4+3d0 which is diamagnetic and colourless.

VOSO4 contains V4+3d1 which is paramagnetic and coloured.

K3CuCN4 contains Cu+3d10 which is diamagnetic and colourless.

Hence, option C is the answer.

So, a=40 g mol-1.

mM of acid=10

questions.chapter: Some Basic Principles of Organic Chemistry
questions.explanation:
The molecules have same molecular formula and different chain lengths are called chain isomers.

Total number of chain isomers possible for C 7 H 16 are four.

 In structural isomerism, also called constitutional isomerism, isomers differ from each other in that the constituent atoms are linked in different ways and sequences. There are several subtypes of structural isomerism: positional, functional group and chain isomerism.

questions.content: The bond order in nitric oxide ( NO ) molecule is b2, then the value of b is
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Bond order =12(Nb−Na)
Nb =  Number of electrons in bonding molecular orbitals.
Na =  Number of electrons in anti-bonding molecular orbitals.
Electronic configuration of NO→σ1s2 σ1s*2 σ2s2 σ2s*2 σ2pz2 π2px2 = π2py2
π2px*1= π2py*0 

Bond order of  NO = 1210−5=2.5 

Hence the value of b=5

questions.content:
Find the mass of nitrogen in 1 kg of KNO3.

The answer should be in grams. Give your answer as the nearest integer

(Atomic masses of K=39 g, N=14 g, O=16 g.)
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Given mass of KNO3=1 kg

We have,

Moles=WeightMolecular mass

So, the moles of KNO3=1000101=9.9 mol

Applying the stoichiometry,

1 mole of KNO3 contains 1 mole of N.

 9.9 moles of KNO3 will contain 9.9 moles of N.

So, the mass of nitrogen = number of moles × atomic weight

=9.9×14 =138.6 g

questions.content:
A 0.50 g mixture of Cu2O and CuO contains 0.425 g of Cu. The mass of CuO in g in the mixture is X. Cu=63.5 u, O=16 u

Then the value of 10X up to the nearest integer.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Let the mass of CuO=w g 

For one mole of Cu2O: mass of Cu=127 g; gram molecular mass=143 g

For one mole of CuO: mass of Cu=63.5 g; gram molecular mass=79.5 g

Thus, for w g CuO, mass of  Cu=63.5w79.5 g

And, for 0.5-w g Cu2O, mass of Cu=1270.5-w143 g

Now, 63.5w79.5 +1270.5-w143 =0.425

w=0.21 g

questions.content: Out of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mi>n</mi></math> consecutive natural numbers, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math> natural numbers are chosen at random without replacement. The probability that the sum of the chosen numbers is divisible by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math>, is
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
In 3n consecutive natural numbers, either

(i) n numbers are of from 3P

(ii) n numbers are of from 3P+1

(iii) n numbers are of from 3P+2

Here favourable number of cases= Either we can select three numbers from any of the set or we can select one from each set

= nC3+ nC3+nC3+( nC1× nC1× nC1)

=3nn-1(n-2)6+n3

=n(n-1(n-2)2+n3

Total number of selections = 3nC3

∴Required probability

=nn-1(n-2)2+n33n3n-1(3n-2)6

=3n2-3n+23n-1(3n-2)

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given: a→=i^+j^ and b→=2i^-k^.

Consider first line:

 r→×a→=b→×a→

⇒r→×a→-b→×a→=0→

⇒a→×(r→-b→)=0→

If  cross product of two vectors is zero, they are parallel and dependent vectors. Hence,

⇒a→∥(r→-b→)

⇒(r→-b→)=λa→

⇒r→=λa→+b→ ...i

Consider the second line,

r→×b→=a→×b→

⇒r→×b→-a→×b→=0→

⇒b→×(r→-a→)=0→

If  cross product of two vectors is zero, they are parallel and dependent vectors. Hence,

⇒b→∥(r→-a→)

⇒(r→-a→)=μb→

⇒r→=μb→+a→ ...ii

From equation (i) and (ii) it is clear that the common point is

a→+b→ →λ=1  μ=1

⇒i^+j^+2i^-k^

⇒3i^+j^-k^=r→

r→=a→+b→=3i^ +j^-k^

questions.explanation:
Given,

So, r→=λ→a→+b→

And |r→|2=14 & α=1

questions.content: Which of the following function is periodic?
questions.subject: Mathematics

options.content: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to the real number <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>

questions.explanation:
Clearly, fx=x-x=x

 which has period 1.

Let sin1x be periodic with period T.

Then, sin1x+T=sin1x

⇒1x+T=nπ+-1n 1x

⇒x=x2+Txnπ+-1nx+T

⇒T=x1--1n-x2nπnπx+-1n

Now for a variable x and constant T, the given relation cannot hold ∀ allowable x. Hence, sin1x is not periodic.

Similarly, for fx=xcosx, let T be the period.

Hence, x+T cosx+T=xcosx

⇒ Tcosx+T=xcosx-cosx+T

⇒ Tcosx+T=2xsinx+T2sinT2

⇒TsinT2=2xsinx+T2cosx+T

Note that LHS is a constant while RHS varies as x varies for allowable values of x. Hence, no such T is possible, so xcosx is also non-periodic.

questions.content: If two circles, each of radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math> unit, touch each other at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and the equation of their common tangent is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, then equation of the circle a portion of which lies in all the quadrants, is
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

The centres of the two circles will lie on the line through P1, 2 perpendicular to the common tangent 4x+3y=10,

If C1 and C2 are the centres of these circles, thenPC1=5=r1, PC2=-5=r2.

Also, C1, C2 lie on the linex-1cosθ=y-2sinθ=r, where tanθ=34 by perpendicular condition of lines,

 When r=r1, then the coordinates of C1 are (5cosθ+1, 5sinθ+2) or (5, 5) as cosθ=45, sinθ=35

When r=r2, then the coordinates of C2 are (-3, -1)

The circle with centre C1(5, 5) and radius 5 touches both the coordinates axes and hence lies completely in the first quadrant.

Therefore, the required circle is with centre (-3, -1) and radius 5,  so its equation is
x+32+y+12=52

⇒x2+y2+6x+2y-15=0

Since, the origin lies inside the circle, a portion of the circle lies in all the quadrants.

questions.content: How many different nine digit numbers can be formed from the number <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>223355888</mn></math> by rearranging its digits so that the odd digits occupy even positions?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given number is 223355888 

It has

four odd digits =3,3,5,5

and five even digits =2,2,8,8,8

Since it is nine-digit number

Position

we have five odd positions = 1 st , 3 rd , 5 th , 7 th , 9 th

and four even positions = 2 nd , 4 th , 6 th , 8 th

So we have exactly 4 odd digits to occupy 4 even positions,

And 5 even digits will occupy the 5 odd position subsequently

Now total number of ways of arranging four odd digits at even positions = 4! 2!2! =6 ....(i)

[Total number of arrangement of ( m+n ) things where 'm' in are alike of one kind and 'n' are alike of another kind = m+n! m!n! ]

Similarly the number of ways of arranging five even digits at odd positions

= 5! 2!3! = 120 2×6 =10 ....(ii)

So total number of nine digit numbers obtained

=6×10=60 [Using multiplication rule of counting] ( ∵ from (i) and (ii))
